title: Code of Conduct in Slack Workspace
text:
We take making our community safe, friendly, and free from harassment and abuse seriously. In order to participate in this Slack workspace all individuals must read and by participating in the Slack community agree to be bound by this Code of Conduct.
This website is brought to you by the ANU Biological Data Science Institute.

title: Code of Conduct in Slack Workspace
text:
Summary

Be respectful, be kind.
Abusive behaviour is never tolerated.
You must use your full name and an image of yourself in your profile in order to participate in the community. Anonymous users who do not edit their profile after being given a warning by the Slack admin team will be removed from the Slack channel.
Should you have any issues while participating in the Slack community you can reach out to one of the teaching team via Direct Message (DM).
Violations of this code of conduct may result in immediate and permanent expulsion from the Slack community.
Any decisions made by the Slack admin team are final.

Current learning objective

-Compute basic summary statistics including mean, median, quartiles, and standard deviation using R

title: Functions, loops and conditional statements
text:
Functions


A function in R has three parts:

formals(): the list of input arguments,
body(): the code inside the function,
environment(): the environment (out of scope for this workshop).

Writing your own functions can make repetitive tasks easier.
You can make a new function using function().




Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Basic troubleshooting
If you encounter an error,

Read the error message!
Google the error message
Ask for help with a reproducible example

title: Functions, loops and conditional statements
text:
üÜò Asking for help

What do you think about the question below?

title: Functions, loops and conditional statements
text:
üÜò Asking for help 1 Part 2

What do you think now?


I am looking to adjust the size of two separate ggplots within the same R chunk in Rmarkdown. These plots must be different when outputted as a pdf, so defining the dimensions at the beginning of the chunk doesn‚Äôt work. Does anyone have any ideas? My code is below.
```{r, fig.height = 3, fig.width = 3}
ggplot(df, aes(weight, height)) +
  geom_point()

ggplot(df, aes(height, volume)) +
  geom_point()
```



could not find function ‚Äúggplot‚Äù
the package needs to be loaded

title: Functions, loops and conditional statements
text:
üÜò Asking for help 1 Part 3

Is this better?


I am looking to adjust the size of two separate ggplots within the same R chunk in Rmarkdown. These plots must be different when outputted as a pdf, so defining the dimensions at the beginning of the chunk doesn‚Äôt work. Does anyone have any ideas? My code is below.
```{r, fig.height = 3, fig.width = 3}
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(df, aes(weight, height)) +
  geom_point()

ggplot(df, aes(height, volume)) +
  geom_point()
```



Data df is not defined!

title: Functions, loops and conditional statements
text:
üÜò Asking for help 1 Part 4

Okay better now?


I am looking to adjust the size of two separate ggplots within the same R chunk in Rmarkdown. These plots must be different when outputted as a pdf, so defining the dimensions at the beginning of the chunk doesn‚Äôt work. Does anyone have any ideas? My code is below.
```{r, fig.height = 3, fig.width = 3}
library(ggplot2)
df <- read.csv("mydata.csv")
ggplot(df, aes(weight, height)) +
  geom_point()

ggplot(df, aes(height, volume)) +
  geom_point()
```



Is the data used in this question necessarily for the question?
Do we even have a copy of mydata.csv??

title: Functions, loops and conditional statements
text:
üÜò Asking for help 1 Part 5

Are we done now?


I am looking to adjust the size of two separate ggplots within the same R chunk in Rmarkdown. These plots must be different when outputted as a pdf, so defining the dimensions at the beginning of the chunk doesn‚Äôt work. Does anyone have any ideas? My code is below.
```{r, fig.height = 3, fig.width = 3}
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(trees, aes(Girth, Height)) +
  geom_point()

ggplot(trees, aes(Height, Volume)) +
  geom_point()
```



Author is using the built-in dataset trees here

title: Functions, loops and conditional statements
text:
Checklist (note: not an exhaustive checklist)
Is the problem clearly and succinctly described?   Is the expected solution or behaviour outlined?   Are you asking the right people at the right place?  
If the question is asked in an public forum or similar:
Can people who can answer your question find your question? E.g. does the post have appropriate tags or keywords to reach the right experts?  
If the problem is computer system related‚Ä¶
Can the problem be easily reproduced on other people‚Äôs system?   Is the minimum reproducible code or steps supplied?  
If the problem is based on data ‚Ä¶
Is the data supplied?   If the data is big, could you cull your data further to communicate or reproduce the problem?

title: Functions, loops and conditional statements
text:
üÜò Asking for help 1 Check





Is the problem clearly and succintly defined?   Is the expected solution or behaviour outlined?   Is the problem asked at the right place or person?  
Can people who can answer your question find your question?  
Can the problem be easily reproduced on other people‚Äôs system?   Is the minimum reproducible code or steps supplied?  
Is the data supplied?   If the data is big, could you cull your data further to communicate or reproduce the problem?

section: üéÅ Reproducible Example with reprex LIVE DEMO
text:
üéÅ Reproducible Example with reprex LIVE DEMO

Copy your minimum reproducible example then run


reprex::reprex(session_info = TRUE)


Once you run the above command, your clipboard contains the formatted code and output for you to paste into places like GitHub issues, Stackoverflow and forums powered by Discourse, e.g.¬†RStudio Community.

title: Working with objects
text:
Current learning objective



-Conduct elementary arithmetic operations using R


-Navigate the RStudio interactive development environment (IDE)


-Compute basic summary statistics including mean, median, quartiles, and standard deviation using R


-Install external packages in R to extend functionality


Comprehend various object types in R


Manipulate lists, matrices, and vectors in R


Grasp the concept of missing values within the R environment


-Import and export data in R


-Create basic functions, employ conditional statements, and utilize for loops in R


-Decipher error messages and do basic troubleshooting

title: Working with objects
text:
Assignment to object

Assignments to object:

You can assign values to objects using <- or =
The name of the object can be variable so long as it is syntactically valid (no spaces and most special characters, and the name cannot start with a digit)



Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Working with objects
text:
Vectors

We can combine scalars to form vectors using c():


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


This is a vector of length 3


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.



This vector is stored as a double with the class as numeric


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Working with objects
text:
Vectors types

There are four primary types of atomic vectors: logical, integer, double and character.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

The integer and double vectors are collectively called numeric vectors.



A vector can only consist of the same type.
If you attempt to combine mismatched types together, it will try to coerce all values to the same type.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Working with objects
text:
Lists

Lists allow to combine elements of different types.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

You can use str() to see the internal structure of an object in R.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Working with objects
text:
Data frames

data.frame is a special type of a named list where each element of the vector is the same length.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Working with objects
text:
Subsetting vectors Part 1

Positive integers select elements at the specified positions:


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


Negative integers exclude elements at the specified positions:


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Working with objects
text:
Subsetting vectors Part 2

Logical vectors select elements where logical value is TRUE.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

If the logical vector used for subsetting a vector is shorter than it then the logical vector is recycled to match the length of the vector.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Working with objects
text:
Subsetting named vectors

Character vectors select elements based on the name of the vector (if any):

title: Working with objects
text:
Missing values


NA in R denotes missing values ‚Äì there are in fact different types of missing values (NA_character_, NA_integer_, NA_real_, NA_complex_).




When there are missing values, it can cause issues in the computation.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.



Below we remove the missing values:


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.




anu-bdsi.github.io/workshop-intro-to-R/

title:
[ANU BDSI
workshop]{.tag-label} Introduction to R programming
text: This website is brought to you by the ANU Biological Data Science Institute.

title: Introduction to R programming
text:
This is a training workshop for staff and students affiliated with the Australian National University (ANU) offered by the ANU Biological Data Science Institute (BDSI).
The workshop is designed to introduce participants to the fundamentals of using R for basic computations. It is suitable for individuals with no prior experience in R or those seeking a refresher in R. Familiarity with basic summary statistics (mean, median, standard deviation, quartiles, etc.) is assumed. It‚Äôs important to note that this workshop alone is not sufficient to practice data analysis. Attendees are encouraged to also participate in the Data Wrangling with R (Part 1) and Data Visualization with R (Part 1) workshops to acquire essential skills for contemporary data wrangling and visualization practices.
This website is brought to you by the ANU Biological Data Science Institute.

title: Introduction to R programming
text:
This is a training workshop for staff and students affiliated with the Australian National University (ANU) offered by the ANU Biological Data Science Institute (BDSI).
The workshop is designed to introduce participants to the fundamentals of using R for basic computations. It is suitable for individuals with no prior experience in R or those seeking a refresher in R. Familiarity with basic summary statistics (mean, median, standard deviation, quartiles, etc.) is assumed. It‚Äôs important to note that this workshop alone is not sufficient to practice data analysis. Attendees are encouraged to also participate in the Data Wrangling with R (Part 1) and Data Visualization with R (Part 1) workshops to acquire essential skills for contemporary data wrangling and visualization practices.

title: Introduction to R programming
text:
Learning objectives
Upon completion of the workshop, participants should be able to:

Conduct elementary arithmetic operations using R
Navigate the RStudio interactive development environment (IDE)
Compute basic summary statistics including mean, median, quartiles, and standard deviation using R
Install external packages in R to extend functionality
Comprehend various object types in R
Manipulate lists, matrices, and vectors in R
Grasp the concept of missing values within the R environment
Import and export data in R
Create basic functions, employ conditional statements, and utilize for loops in R
Decipher error messages and do basic troubleshooting

title: Introduction to R programming
text:
Preperation
Please ensure that you download and install

the latest version of R,
the latest version of RStudio Desktop,
Slack (alternatively you can use the web version), and

 If you are having issues, ask in the slack channel or talk to the teaching team.






 Slack workspace




Join ANU Learning Data Slack Community


You must use your ANU email to sign up.
Use your full name.
By joining, you agree to abide by this code of conduct.
Please don‚Äôt direct message the teaching team in Slack. Your questions are more likely to be answered in the Slack channels rather than in direct messages.

title: Getting Started
text:
What is R?



R is a programming language predominately for data analysis.







RStudio Desktop is an integrated development environment (IDE) that helps you to use R.






Visual Studio Code is another popular IDE (we don‚Äôt use this).

title: Getting Started
text:
Why learn R?


R is one of the top programming languages for statistics or data science.

Python is also a good alternative language for data science.
Better to have a mastery of at least one language rather than none.

R was initially developed by statisticians for statisticians.

State-of-the-art statistical methods are more readily available in R.

R has a very active and friendly community.
R is a free and open source software (FOSS) and is a cross-platform language:

free = money is not a barrier to use it,
open source software = transparency,
cross-platform = can be used on Windows, Mac, and Linux.

title: Getting Started
text:
Rapid development

Access to Open AI (known for ChatGPT) API is already available in R!


library(openai)
out <- create_image("A data scientist with a laptop and 
                     statistical software in an anime style")

title: Getting Started
text:
Rich graphical outputs

R also has a wide range of packages for creating beautiful and interactive graphics.

 Try clicking on a bar on the left plot.

title: Getting Started
text:
Dynamic documents



Create beautiful documents with better reproducible practices and workflow!
This slide and the website is made using a combination of R and Quarto.






scroll down

title: Getting Started
text:
Interactively working with R

You can use R like a calculator:


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Getting Started
text:
How do you use R?

RStudio Desktop (or RStudio IDE) is the most common way to use R.

title: Getting Started
text:
Customise Global Options



Go to RStudio > Tools > Global Options‚Ä¶
Under the General tab, make sure the ‚ÄúRestore .RData into workspace at startup‚Äù is unticked.
This avoids unexpectedly loading (old) data into your workspace and making your code only work in your workspace, but not for others (which is bad reproducible practice).

title: Getting Started
text:
Arithmetics

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Getting Started
text:
Vectors

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Getting Started
text:
Functions

There are many functions in R.
You can look at the documentation on how to use it:


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Getting Started
text:
Numerical summaries

Numerical summaries generally come base or stats package.
Some common numerical summaries include:

Mean: mean()
Median: median()
Five number summary: fivenum()
Minimum: min()
Maximum: max()
Quantile: quantile()
Correlation coefficient: cor()

title: Getting Started
text:
Finding functions

To find indexed functions for a package:


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


Google it with a good set of keywords.
The recent trend is ask generative AI.

title: Getting Started
text:
Base R






R has 7 packages, collectively referred to as the ‚Äúbase R‚Äù, that are loaded automatically when you launch it.
The functions in the base packages are generally well-tested and trustworthy.

title: Getting Started
text:
Contributed R Packages




R packages are community developed extensions to R (much like apps on your mobile)
The Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN) is a volunteer maintained repository that hosts submitted R packages that are approved (much like an app store)
There are close to 20,000 packages available on CRAN but the qualities of R packages vary.
There are other repositories that host R packages, e.g.¬†Bioconductor for bioinformatics, R Universe, R-Forge, GitHub (we won‚Äôt cover these).





Photo by Sara Kurfe√ü on Unsplash

title: Getting Started
text:
Using packages on CRAN


If the package (say praise) is on CRAN, you can install it by:

install.packages("praise")

You only need to install.packages() once!

title: Getting Started
text:
What is R?



R is a programming language predominately for data analysis.







RStudio Desktop is an integrated development environment (IDE) that helps you to use R.






Visual Studio Code is another popular IDE (we don‚Äôt use this).

title: Getting Started
text:
Why learn R?


R is one of the top programming languages for statistics or data science.

Python is also a good alternative language for data science.
Better to have a mastery of at least one language rather than none.

R was initially developed by statisticians for statisticians.

State-of-the-art statistical methods are more readily available in R.

R has a very active and friendly community.
R is a free and open source software (FOSS) and is a cross-platform language:

free = money is not a barrier to use it,
open source software = transparency,
cross-platform = can be used on Windows, Mac, and Linux.

title: Getting Started
text:
Rapid development

Access to Open AI (known for ChatGPT) API is already available in R!


library(openai)
out <- create_image("A data scientist with a laptop and 
                     statistical software in an anime style")

title: Getting Started
text:
Rich graphical outputs

R also has a wide range of packages for creating beautiful and interactive graphics.

 Try clicking on a bar on the left plot.




Rows: 77 Columns: 5

chr (4): affiliation, workshop, comment, role
dbl (1): confidence

Create beautiful documents with better reproducible practices and workflow!
This slide and the website is made using a combination of R and Quarto.

Interactively working with R

You can use R like a calculator:

title: Getting Started
text:
How do you use R?

RStudio Desktop (or RStudio IDE) is the most common way to use R.

title: Getting Started
text:
Customise Global Options



Go to RStudio > Tools > Global Options‚Ä¶
Under the General tab, make sure the ‚ÄúRestore .RData into workspace at startup‚Äù is unticked.
This avoids unexpectedly loading (old) data into your workspace and making your code only work in your workspace, but not for others (which is bad reproducible practice).

title: Getting Started
text:
Functions

There are many functions in R.
You can look at the documentation on how to use it:


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Getting Started
text:
Numerical summaries

Numerical summaries generally come base or stats package.
Some common numerical summaries include:

Mean: mean()
Median: median()
Five number summary: fivenum()
Minimum: min()
Maximum: max()
Quantile: quantile()
Correlation coefficient: cor()

title: Getting Started
text:
Finding functions

To find indexed functions for a package:


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


Google it with a good set of keywords.
The recent trend is ask generative AI.

title: Getting Started
text:
Base R






R has 7 packages, collectively referred to as the ‚Äúbase R‚Äù, that are loaded automatically when you launch it.
The functions in the base packages are generally well-tested and trustworthy.

title: Getting Started
text:
Contributed R Packages




R packages are community developed extensions to R (much like apps on your mobile)
The Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN) is a volunteer maintained repository that hosts submitted R packages that are approved (much like an app store)
There are close to 20,000 packages available on CRAN but the qualities of R packages vary.
There are other repositories that host R packages, e.g.¬†Bioconductor for bioinformatics, R Universe, R-Forge, GitHub (we won‚Äôt cover these).

title: Reading and writing data
text:
Current learning objective



-Conduct elementary arithmetic operations using R


-Navigate the RStudio interactive development environment (IDE)


-Compute basic summary statistics including mean, median, quartiles, and standard deviation using R


-Install external packages in R to extend functionality


-Comprehend various object types in R


-Manipulate lists, matrices, and vectors in R


-Grasp the concept of missing values within the R environment


Import and export data in R


-Create basic functions, employ conditional statements, and utilize for loops in R


-Decipher error messages and do basic troubleshooting

title: Reading and writing data
text:
Data file formats


Data are stored as a file, which points to a block of computer memory.
A file format signals a way to interpret the information stored in the computer memory.
A file with the extension ‚Äúcsv‚Äù (comma-separated values) uses a comma as a delimiter while ‚Äútsv‚Äù uses tabs as a delimiter.




data.csv

len, supp, dose
4.2, VC, 0.5
11.5, VC, 0.5
...



A common approach is to have as a text file format where

a delimiter (e.g.¬†‚Äú,‚Äù and tabs) separate columns,
the first row (header) corresponds to the names of the variables, and
subsequent rows correspond to the values.

title: Reading and writing data
text:
Binary or propriety file formats


Data can also be stored as a binary format (in R, these include .RData and .rda but we won‚Äôt cover this).
Data can also come in a propriety format (e.g.¬†xls and xlsx) ‚Äì these require special ways to open/view/read it.

title: Reading and writing data
text:
Formatting data


Unless you are responsible for entering the data, you should never modify the original, stored data (note: exceptions do apply).
For scientific integrity, any modification to the original data should be recorded in a reproducible manner (e.g.¬†by programming in R!) so that you can trace the exact modifications.

title: Reading and writing data
text:
Importing data

Reading data into R requires using the function that matches with the right file format.



For reading csv file, you can use readr::read_csv() (note: readr is part of tidyverse)

cfdata <- readr::read_csv("complex-formation.csv")



For reading excel files, you can use readxl::read_xlsx:


kingston <- readxl::read_xlsx("kingston-data.xlsx", sheet = "A")



Error: `path` does not exist: 'kingston-data.xlsx'





But why the error?!

title: Reading and writing data
text:
File paths



Your file has to be in the right location to be read!
You may use a relative path (e.g.¬†data/data.csv) or an absolute path (e.g.¬†C:\\user/myproject/data/data.csv) to point to the right location of the data
 You should avoid using absolute path! Why?
You can get and set the current path using getwd() and setwd(), respectively.

title: Reading and writing data
text:
Folder structure

Your folder structure depends on the project, but it is generally a good idea to have a folder on its own for each project.



Within the project, it is also good to have a separate folder for:

data
script/analysis
report/paper
figures/images.

title: Reading and writing data
text:
R project


Within RStudio, you can create a project file (with an .Rproj extension).
Double clicking on this project file launches RStudio Desktop with the current working directory set to the location of the project file.
You can create this project file by going to RStudio > File > New Project ‚Ä¶






anu-bdsi.github.io/workshop-intro-to-R/

title: Wrap-up
section: How to get better at R?
text:
How to get better at R?
PRACTICE

Practice with a purpose (e.g.¬†using R on your own data).
Try teaching and helping others with their R problem.
Have a willingness to continuously learn and adapt.

R is an ever evolving language (check the release news every so often),
new features and packages are added very frequently,
whether you are a beginner or not, there are always things we do not know about R.

title: Wrap-up
text: Joining the R community

title: Help
text:
You aren‚Äôt alone in your R journey. Make use of the experiences of those around you.
This website is brought to you by the ANU Biological Data Science Institute.

title: Help
text:
During the workshop

Don‚Äôt be shy and ask fellow participants in the workshop.
Flag and ask the teaching team.

title: Help
text:
Outside of the workshop

Ask people around you. A second opinion is often helpful in uncovering a step towards the solution to your problem.
Ask the local experts such as at the BDSI Drop-In Sessions and ANU Statistical Support Network.
Use online resources such as:

Online Statistics Courses by ANU Statistical Support Network
R Project Sharepoint Resources by ANU Statistical Support Network
R for Data Science
R4DS Online Learning Community
Ask questions on Stack Overflow or Posit Community.

You can continue to use the ANU Learning Data Slack Community to connect with each other.

title: Help
text:
Reporting mistakes
Did you find mistakes in the workshop? Please let us know either by either emailing Emi (emi.tanaka@anu.edu.au) or reporting it at https://github.com/anu-bdsi/training-R1/issues (latter preferred).

title: Help
text:
Providing feedback
We want to always improve our delivery! Please let us know what is working, what is not working, and/or other feedback. For feedback, you can either email Emi (emi.tanaka@anu.edu.au) or use the survey link that was/will be emailed to you (for workshop participants).
